citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection an updated program of veterinary care, contingency plan, record of animals on hand,
environmental enhancement program for non-human primates, and records of acquisition for the ring-tailed lemur,
capybaras, and sloths were not available for review by the inspector. The review of records required by the Animal
Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal
welfare. The licensee must, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by the
Animal Welfare Act and the regulations. Correction date: May 3, 2023.

There are 11 rabbit cages, each containing one adult rabbit and a water bottle attached to the outside of the cage. Each
water bottle has dark green material adhered to the inside surface. The presence of this material indicates the bottles are
not sanitized frequently enough. Unsanitary water bottles can contaminate water and cause it to be unhealthy or
unpalatable to the animals, leading to illness. All watering receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty and at a minimum of
every two weeks. Correction date: April 28, 2023.

The wire cages housing 11 adult rabbits have excessive accumulations of feces in the areas underneath them. Poor
cleaning and sanitation increase risk hazards such as mold, mildew, insects, and vermin. These areas shall be cleaned
and managed to prevent accumulations, decrease odors, and protect the health and well-being of the rabbits. These
areas under the rabbit enclosures must be cleaned at least once each week. Correction date: April 28, 2023.

The facility which houses kangaroos, capybaras, sloths, and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, does not have an
adequate perimeter fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall. A
perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a
secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing a perimeter fence
that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a secondary containment system
for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the APHIS Administrator. Correction
date: July 26, 2023.

The goat and sheep water receptacles are covered in thick, slimy green-brown material and/or have cloudy water with
debris floating on the surface. Dirty water receptacles contaminate water and may lead to animal illness. Water
receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary to provide water that is free from contamination. Correction date: April
28,2023.

In a goat enclosure housing 11 goats, there is an excessive accumulation of feces on the ground, covering the majority of
the open and sheltered areas. There is also an excessive accumulation of feces in a stall housing a single bison. Feces
accumulation attracts pests and increases the likelihood of disease for the animals. Feces must be removed as often as
necessary to prevent contamination of the animals and reduce hazards and odors. Correction date: April 28,2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection an updated program of veterinary care, contingency plan, record of animals on hand, 
environmental enhancement program for non-human primates, and records of acquisition for the ring-tailed lemur, 
capybaras, and sloths were not available for review by the inspector. The review of records required by the Animal

welfare. The licensee must, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by the 
Animal Welfare Act and the regulations. Correction date: May 3, 2023. 
3.55 
   
Watering. 
There are 11 rabbit cages, each containing one adult rabbit and a water bottle attached to the outside of the cage. Each 
water bottle has dark green material adhered to the inside surface. The presence of this material indicates the bottles are 
not sanitized frequently enough. Unsanitary water bottles can contaminate water and cause it to be unhealthy or 
unpalatable to the animals, leading to illness. All watering receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty and at a minimum of 
every two weeks. Correction date: April 28, 2023. 
3.56(a)(3) 
   
Sanitation.

The wire cages housing 11 adult rabbits have excessive accumulations of feces in the areas underneath them. Poor 
cleaning and sanitation increase risk hazards such as mold, mildew, insects, and vermin. These areas shall be cleaned 
and managed to prevent accumulations, decrease odors, and protect the health and well-being of the rabbits. These 
areas under the rabbit enclosures must be cleaned at least once each week. Correction date: April 28, 2023. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility which houses kangaroos, capybaras, sloths, and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, does not have an 
adequate perimeter fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall. A 
perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a 
secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing a perimeter fence 
that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a secondary containment system 
for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the APHIS Administrator. Correction 
date: July 26, 2023. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
The goat and sheep water receptacles are covered in thick, slimy green-brown material and/or have cloudy water with 
debris floating on the surface. Dirty water receptacles contaminate water and may lead to animal illness. Water 
receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary to provide water that is free from contamination. Correction date: April 
28,2023. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation.

In a goat enclosure housing 11 goats, there is an excessive accumulation of feces on the ground, covering the majority of 
the open and sheltered areas. There is also an excessive accumulation of feces in a stall housing a single bison. Feces 
accumulation attracts pests and increases the likelihood of disease for the animals. Feces must be removed as often as 
necessary to prevent contamination of the animals and reduce hazards and odors. Correction date: April 28,2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
